path_1.title: Sarfarosh (1999)
path_1.feeling: Gritty and purposeful, it pulled me in with its grounded stakes and conviction.

path_1.title: Now You See Me 2 (2016)
path_1.feeling: Flashy fun but too slick for its own good.

path_1.title: Inside Out (2015)
path_1.feeling: Smart, heartfelt storytelling that hit the right emotional notes.

path_1.title: Hugo (2011)
path_1.feeling: A warm, elegant ode to cinema that felt gently engaging.

path_1.title: Hera Pheri (2000)
path_1.feeling: Chaotic, quotable fun that still lands with sharp comic timing.

path_1.title: Match Point (2005)
path_1.feeling: Cold, tense moral intrigue that kept me hooked.

path_1.title: Dil Dosti Etc (2007)
path_1.feeling: Interesting ideas about youth and arrogance, uneven but watchable.

path_1.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_1.feeling: Classic chills, though the horror didn’t fully get under my skin.

path_1.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_1.feeling: Disturbing and bleak, compelling more for its investigation than its brutality.

path_1.title: Rustom (2016)
path_1.feeling: A tidy, crowd-pleasing courtroom thriller with just enough bite.

path_1.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_1.feeling: Awe-inspiring and deeply affecting, the kind of sci‑fi that stays with me.

path_1.title: Ishqiya (2010)
path_1.feeling: Smoky, witty, and twisty with irresistible performances.

path_1.title: ...And Justice for All (1979)
path_1.feeling: An angry, engaging legal drama that scratches the corruption itch.

path_1.title: Ghajini (2005)
path_1.feeling: High-energy revenge with a hook that kept me invested.

path_1.title: The Jungle Book (2016)
path_1.feeling: Lush and lively, a solid adventure with heart.

path_1.title: Drive (2011)
path_1.feeling: Moody, stylish tension with a quiet emotional core.

path_1.title: Lootera (2013)
path_1.feeling: Poetic and melancholic, its restrained romance won me over.

path_1.title: Live Free or Die Hard (2007)
path_1.feeling: Serviceable spectacle that goes down easy and fades fast.

path_1.title: Before We Go (2014)
path_1.feeling: Pleasant nighttime stroll vibes, modest but charming enough.

path_1.title: Meet the Parents (2000)
path_1.feeling: Cringe comedy that lands thanks to tight setups and payoffs.

path_1.title: Love Per Square Foot (2018)
path_1.feeling: Light, relatable urban rom-com with a likable spark.

path_1.title: Fargo (1996)
path_1.feeling: Darkly funny and razor sharp, a masterclass in crime storytelling.

path_1.title: Source Code (2011)
path_1.feeling: Lean, clever sci‑fi thriller that kept me engaged throughout.

path_1.title: Inception (2010)
path_1.feeling: Inventive and propulsive, brainy thrills with heart.

path_1.title: Jerry Maguire (1996)
path_1.feeling: Earnest and crowd-pleasing with solid character beats.

path_1.title: Spider-Man (2002)
path_1.feeling: Straightforward, heartfelt origin story that still charms.

path_1.title: Rocky III (1982)
path_1.feeling: Energetic comeback chapter that keeps the fighter spirit alive.

path_1.title: Sultan (2016)
path_1.feeling: Rousing sports melodrama with enough emotional stakes to work.

path_3.feeling: College ego games that interest me more in idea than in execution.

path_3.title: ...And Justice for All (1979)
path_3.feeling: Angry, morally charged courtroom drama that lands its punches.

path_3.title: Love Per Square Foot (2018)

path_3.title: Fargo (1996)

path_3.title: Source Code (2011)

path_3.title: Inception (2010)
path_3.feeling: Propulsive, clever dream heist that satisfies my puzzle-loving side.

path_3.title: Spider-Man (2002)
path_3.feeling: Earnest origin ride with rousing beats, even if it feels a bit dated now.

path_3.title: Rocky III (1982)
path_3.feeling: Rousing training-and-redemption chapter that hits the familiar beats well.

path_3.title: Sultan (2016)
path_3.feeling: Broad, melodramatic sports saga that entertains but doesn’t fully land its emotional heft for me.

path_3.title: Sarfarosh (1999)
path_3.feeling: Sturdy, purpose-driven cop thriller whose patriotic edge and procedure kept me engaged.

path_3.title: Now You See Me 2 (2016)
path_3.feeling: Flashy sleight-of-hand that entertained in bursts but felt hollow and overcooked.

path_3.title: Inside Out (2015)
path_3.feeling: Inventive, heartfelt journey that balanced clever world-building with genuine emotion.

path_3.title: Hugo (2011)
path_3.feeling: Gorgeous clockwork fable that charmed more in craft than in momentum for me.

path_3.title: Hera Pheri (2000)
path_3.feeling: Chaotic, quotable caper whose scrappy energy landed more laughs than groans.

path_3.title: Match Point (2005)
path_3.feeling: Chilly, gripping morality play where ambition curdles into suspense.

path_3.title: Dil Dosti Etc (2007)
path_3.feeling: A candid campus detour with sparks of insight that never fully cohere.

path_3.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_3.feeling: Atmospheric and unsettling in stretches, yet its impact felt more historic than harrowing to me.

path_3.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_3.feeling: Relentless, grim precision that burrowed under my skin and stayed there.

path_3.title: Rustom (2016)
path_3.feeling: Glossy, diverting courtroom melodrama that skims when I wanted it to cut deeper.

path_3.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_3.feeling: A sweeping, emotional sci-fi odyssey that thrilled my head and heart.

path_3.title: Ishqiya (2010)
path_3.feeling: Smoky, sly caper with sharp turns and a magnetic femme fatale.

path_3.title: ...And Justice for All (1979)
path_3.feeling: Righteous, frayed legal howl whose moral outrage still stings.

path_3.title: Ghajini (2005)
path_3.feeling: Punchy revenge melodrama whose amnesia hook entertained more than it surprised.

path_3.title: The Jungle Book (2016)
path_3.feeling: Lush, lively adventure that impressed visually even as it stayed a touch safe.

path_3.title: Drive (2011)
path_3.feeling: Cool, neon-noir pulse where restrained menace and bursts of violence hit just right.

path_3.title: Lootera (2013)
path_3.feeling: Elegantly melancholic romance whose languid grace moved me in pockets.

path_3.title: Live Free or Die Hard (2007)
path_3.feeling: Serviceable, louder-than-necessary sequel that trades grit for glossy excess.

path_3.title: Before We Go (2014)
path_3.feeling: Gentle, meandering night-walk that charmed lightly but never truly sparked.

path_3.title: Meet the Parents (2000)
path_3.feeling: Awkward-comedy machine that delivers reliable cringe and laughs.

path_3.title: Love Per Square Foot (2018)
path_3.feeling: A pleasant, urban rom-com with likable leads that plays it comfortably safe.

path_3.title: Fargo (1996)
path_3.feeling: Bleakly funny, quietly ruthless crime spiral anchored by an unforgettable moral center.

path_3.title: Source Code (2011)
path_3.feeling: Tight, clever sci-fi loop whose urgency and puzzle pieces clicked satisfyingly.

path_3.title: Inception (2010)
path_3.feeling: A propulsive, brainy heist that dazzled me with layers and momentum.

path_3.title: Jerry Maguire (1996)
path_3.feeling: Warm, crowd-pleasing redemption tale that worked even if it ran a bit long.

path_3.title: Spider-Man (2002)
path_3.feeling: Earnest, bright origin ride that holds up on heart more than polish.

path_3.title: Rocky III (1982)
path_3.feeling: Punchy, motivational middle chapter that trades nuance for rousing beats.

path_3.title: Sultan (2016)
path_3.feeling: Broad, earnest sports melodrama that hits familiar notes with intermittent lift.

path_3.title: Sarfarosh (1999)
path_3.feeling: A sturdy, engaging cop procedural whose patriotic grit and investigative momentum hit my sweet spot even when the melodrama peeks through.

path_3.title: Now You See Me 2 (2016)
path_3.feeling: Flashy, over-plotted caper that amuses in bursts but mistakes swagger and CGI for genuine sleight of hand.

path_3.title: Inside Out (2015)
path_3.feeling: Inventive, heartfelt journey through growing pains that balanced clever ideas with real warmth.

path_3.title: Hugo (2011)
path_3.feeling: A lovingly crafted ode to cinema that charmed me more for its craft than it moved me.

path_3.title: Hera Pheri (2000)
path_3.feeling: Broad, chaotic comedy of errors that lands enough gags and scrappy charm to keep me grinning.

path_3.title: Match Point (2005)
path_3.feeling: A cool, morally queasy ascent where luck and desire curdle into a crisp, unsettling thriller.

path_3.title: Dil Dosti Etc (2007)
path_3.feeling: An uneven campus drift whose ambition shows even as its bite and payoff feel modest.

path_3.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_3.feeling: Classic possession chills that I respect more than I truly fear, effective but a bit dated for me.

path_3.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_3.feeling: Relentless, rain-soaked descent with an uncompromising sting that lingered.

path_3.title: Rustom (2016)
path_3.feeling: Glossy, pulpy courtroom potboiler whose crowd-pleasing turns blunt the moral complexity I crave.

path_3.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_3.feeling: Grand, emotionally charged sci‑fi that married heady ideas with soaring heart and left me awed.

path_3.title: Ishqiya (2010)
path_3.feeling: A sly, smoky mix of desire and duplicity whose dark humor and twists kept me hooked.

path_3.title: ...And Justice for All (1979)
path_3.feeling: A bristling, cynical legal screed that works as both character study and indictment.

path_3.title: Ghajini (2005)
path_3.feeling: High-decibel revenge melodrama with a hook that entertains but sacrifices nuance for impact.

path_3.title: The Jungle Book (2016)
path_3.feeling: Lush, immersive spectacle that delivers sturdy adventure even if it stays emotionally straightforward.

path_3.title: Drive (2011)
path_3.feeling: Moody, minimalist crime romance punctured by bursts of sharp, brutal violence.

path_3.title: Lootera (2013)
path_3.feeling: A tender, painterly romance whose hushed melancholy moved me even as its languor held me at a slight remove.

path_3.title: Live Free or Die Hard (2007)
path_3.feeling: Serviceable, outsized sequel fun that trades grit for cartoonish escalation.

path_3.title: Before We Go (2014)
path_3.feeling: A pleasant, low-key overnight connection that charms more than it lingers.

path_3.title: Meet the Parents (2000)
path_3.feeling: Broad, cringe-forward comedy that earns laughs even as it leans on repetition.

path_3.title: Love Per Square Foot (2018)
path_3.feeling: A breezy, likable rom-com with relatable stakes that goes down easy if unsurprising.

path_3.feeling: Bleakly funny, quietly tense snowbound noir whose humane bite and dread balanced beautifully.

path_3.title: Source Code (2011)
path_3.feeling: A tight, clever loop-thriller that blends propulsion with just enough heart.

path_3.title: Inception (2010)
path_3.feeling: Inventive, propulsive dream-heist that satisfied my puzzle itch and adrenaline in tandem.

path_5.feeling: Broad, chaotic caper with laughs, but the shtick is hit-and-miss for me.

path_5.title: Match Point (2005)
path_5.feeling: A cool, morally taut obsession tale that scratched my noir itch.

path_5.title: Dil Dosti Etc (2007)
path_5.feeling: Restless campus drama with ideas that intrigue more than they land.

path_5.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_5.feeling: A classic, chilly possession tale I respect more than I love.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: Grim, brutal true-crime horrors that left me more numb than engrossed.

path_5.title: Rustom (2016)
path_5.feeling: Compelling true-crime courtroom ride with enough twists to keep me hooked.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Awe-filled, human sci-fi that sweeps me away every time.

path_5.title: Ishqiya (2010)
path_5.feeling: Twisty, witty and seductive—right in my sweet spot.

path_5.title: ...And Justice for All (1979)
path_5.feeling: A biting legal morality play that had me riled and invested.

path_5.title: Ghajini (2005)
path_5.feeling: High-energy amnesia revenge with heart—gripping even when familiar.

path_5.title: The Jungle Book (2016)
path_5.feeling: Lush, warm-hearted adventure that entertained me well enough.

path_5.title: Drive (2011)
path_5.feeling: Cool, restrained neo-noir with tension and melancholy that hit home.

path_5.title: Lootera (2013)
path_5.feeling: An elegant, hushed romance that lingered, if a tad slow.

path_5.title: Live Free or Die Hard (2007)
path_5.feeling: Big, slick mayhem—serviceable thrills with thin stakes.

path_5.title: Before We Go (2014)
path_5.feeling: A sweet, low-key night-in-the-city stroll that’s pleasant if slight.

path_5.title: Meet the Parents (2000)
path_5.feeling: Cringe-y family farce with enough laughs, even as it wears thin.

path_5.title: Love Per Square Foot (2018)
path_5.feeling: A charming housing-hustle romance that plays it safe but likable.

path_5.title: Fargo (1996)
path_5.feeling: Darkly funny, humane crime tale—precise, tense, and absorbing.

path_5.title: Source Code (2011)
path_5.feeling: A smart, propulsive loop-thriller that scratched my sci-fi itch.

path_5.title: Inception (2010)
path_5.feeling: Ingenious, heady heist that thrills and stimulates in equal measure.

path_5.title: Jerry Maguire (1996)
path_5.feeling: An earnest, crowd-pleasing character turn that worked on me.

path_5.title: Spider-Man (2002)
path_5.feeling: Classic-origin fun—engaging even if the formula shows.

path_5.title: Rocky III (1982)
path_5.feeling: Rousing, familiar underdog beats that still land.

path_5.title: Sultan (2016)
path_5.feeling: A crowd-pleasing comeback saga with enough heart to carry the punches.

path_5.title: Sarfarosh (1999)
path_5.feeling: Tense, grounded anti-terror drama that scratches my procedural-thriller itch.

path_5.title: Now You See Me 2 (2016)
path_5.feeling: Slick, busy fun whose flashy twists amuse more than they thrill.

path_5.title: Inside Out (2015)
path_5.feeling: Inventive, heartfelt family adventure that hit sweet, relatable notes.

path_5.title: Hugo (2011)
path_5.feeling: A lovingly crafted ode to cinema that warmed me even at a gentle pace.

path_5.title: Hera Pheri (2000)
path_5.feeling: Chaotic caper comedy with enough sharp gags to keep me grinning.

path_5.title: Match Point (2005)
path_5.feeling: A cool, morally coiled thriller that pulled me in.

path_5.title: Dil Dosti Etc (2007)
path_5.feeling: Engaging campus angst with ideas that intrigue more than fully land.

path_5.title: Exorcist, The (1973)
path_5.feeling: Classic dread and atmosphere I respect more than I love.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: Grim, skillful crime horror that impressed me but left me cold.

path_5.title: Rustom (2016)
path_5.feeling: Glossy courtroom-crime melodrama that kept me engaged.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Awe, emotion, and big-idea sci‑fi that hits me squarely.

path_5.title: Ishqiya (2010)
path_5.feeling: Witty, smoky crime-romance with crackling performances.

path_5.title: ...And Justice for All (1979)
path_5.feeling: Angry legal drama whose moral knots hooked me.

path_5.title: Ghajini (2005)
path_5.feeling: High-voltage amnesia revenge that’s compelling if broad.

path_5.title: The Jungle Book (2016)
path_5.feeling: A handsome, lively retelling that delivers sturdy family adventure.

path_5.title: Drive (2011)
path_5.feeling: Moody, lean neo-noir whose style and quiet menace worked for me.

path_5.title: Lootera (2013)
path_5.feeling: Elegantly restrained romance that lingered.

path_5.title: Live Free or Die Hard (2007)
path_5.feeling: Serviceable, outsized action ride—entertaining, disposable.

path_5.title: Before We Go (2014)
path_5.feeling: A gentle, low-key night-walk romance that’s pleasant more than profound.

path_5.title: Meet the Parents (2000)
path_5.feeling: Well-oiled cringe-comedy that amuses even as it leans broad.

path_5.title: Love Per Square Foot (2018)
path_5.feeling: A likable, light rom-com with relatable stakes.

path_5.title: Fargo (1996)
path_5.feeling: A darkly funny, chilly crime spiral that hit the spot.

path_5.title: Source Code (2011)
path_5.feeling: A tight, clever sci‑fi thriller that kept me gripped.

path_5.title: Inception (2010)
path_5.feeling: Ingenious, propulsive mind-heist that satisfies both head and heart.

path_5.title: Jerry Maguire (1996)
path_5.feeling: Crowd-pleasing sincerity and character beats that mostly work for me.

path_5.title: Spider-Man (2002)
path_5.feeling: Classic, earnest superhero fare—solid, if not my sweet spot.

path_5.title: Rocky III (1982)
path_5.feeling: Punchy sequel energy with satisfying training-and-redemption beats.
